awd_titl_txt: Developing a Computing Application Minor and an Inclusive Learning Environment to Build the Diverse, Multidisciplinary Computer Science Workforce of the Future
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to address two pressing needs in STEM education: 1) increasing the number of students graduating with expertise in data and computer science; and 2) improving diversity in STEM fields. The project team at San Francisco State University (SFSU) will achieve these goals by developing and implementing a Computing Application minor.  This minor will use evidence-based approaches to attract, retain, and support students, with attention to students from groups that are underrepresented in computer/data science, including female students. By tailoring activities to students' majors, the project expects to increase student engagement and help students experience how data and computer science are applied in their majors and future professions. Students in the minor will have opportunities to work with local industry and governmental agencies.  In addition, this project will link to the NSF INCLUDES project at SFSU.  As a result, the Computing Application minors will be able to work with high school students as computer science mentors and role models. These experiences can support development of critical skills, including leadership.  The project aims to provide a sustainable and scalable model for introducing data and computer science to science majors that can be adopted by other institutions, and that can broaden participation in those fields.

The Computing Application minor will be a four-semester, five-course sequence designed for STEM students who have no prior computer/data science knowledge and who are taking a full course load in their major. The project will provide participating students with learning experiences related to their majors, train computer science faculty in evidence-based science teaching methods, and invite students to share their knowledge with the K-12 community. To reduce stereotype threat and imposter syndrome, the project will employ a cohort-based structure that uses peer, faculty, and industry mentors to create a nurturing and supportive community of learners. The project will identify pedagogies that promote students' interest in computer/data science and their motivation to use it in their majors.  These research results can inform other efforts to broaden the diversity of people who have computational expertise, and who decide to pursue graduate degrees and careers in computer/data science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview The PINC (Promoting Inclusivity in Computing) project aimed to establish an interdisciplinary Computing Application minor to attract students from underrepresented groups in computer science (CS). Over six years, the project not only met its initial goals but also exceeded them by developing two professional certificate programs, collaborating with industry partners such as Genentech, and fostering a supportive learning community. This report highlights the outcomes and broader impacts of the project, demonstrating significant strides in both intellectual merit and societal contributions.

Intellectual Merit The PINC project developed a unique curriculum that integrates biology and computer science. This interdisciplinary approach enabled students from life sciences to acquire computational skills essential for modern scientific research. The curriculum, refined over multiple iterations, now includes:

  • PINC Minor: A 15-unit interdisciplinary program designed for life science students.

  • Data Science and Machine Learning Certificate: A 12-unit program targeting students interested in biotechnology applications.

  • Professional Certificate for Genentech Employees: A 15-unit asynchronous program co-developed with Genentech, tailored for working professionals.

These programs collectively enhanced computational literacy among students and working professionals. The project also created state-of-the-art teaching materials, such as hands-on projects and lecture videos, to ensure effective learning.

Broader Impacts

  1. Increasing Diversity in STEM: The project focused on supporting students from underrepresented backgrounds. Among nearly 600 students who participated in the program, 27.8% identified as Hispanic/Latinx, and 48% were women. This diverse cohort gained valuable skills and many transitioned to graduate programs or industry roles.

  2. Student Success Stories: Several PINC alumni have achieved significant milestones:

    • Internships at leading companies such as Genentech and GitHub.

    • Acceptance into prestigious graduate programs, including Carnegie Mellon University and UC Davis.

    • Recognition by NSF, with one student receiving a Graduate Research Fellowship (GRFP) and another earning an honorable mention.

  3. Industry Collaboration: Collaboration with Genentech led to the creation of scholarships, professional development workshops, and mock interview sessions. Over 67 students benefited from Gen-PINC scholarships, which provided financial support and reduced barriers to participation.

  4. Mentorship and Community Building: The program emphasized near-peer mentorship to foster a sense of community. PINC mentors, often alumni of the program, guided new students through their coursework and professional development. Monthly mentor training sessions ensured the quality and consistency of support provided.

  5. Expansion to Other Programs: Inspired by the success of PINC, additional grants were secured to expand peer mentoring and redesign introductory CS courses across San Francisco State University (SFSU) and other CSU campuses. These initiatives aim to improve retention and engagement among historically marginalized students in computing.

Key Outcomes

  • Curriculum Development: Successful institutionalization of the PINC minor and certificate programs.

  • Student Achievements: Significant placements in internships, jobs, and graduate schools.

  • Professional Development: Enhanced industry readiness through seminars and mock interviews.

  • Dissemination: Presentations at conferences and publications in peer-reviewed journals.

Conclusion The PINC project has had a profound impact on students, faculty, and industry partners by fostering inclusivity in computer science education. Through innovative curriculum design, robust community building, and strategic industry collaboration, the project has set a benchmark for interdisciplinary education and broadened participation in STEM fields. As the program continues to evolve, its legacy will inspire further initiatives aimed at creating equitable learning environments in computing.

For more information, please visit https://pinc.sfsu.edu.

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2025
Modified by: Ilmi Yoon

Over six years, the project not only met its initial goals but also exceeded them by developing two professional certificate programs, collaborating with industry partners such as Genentech, and fostering a supportive learning community. This report highlights the outcomes and broader impacts of the project, demonstrating significant strides in both intellectual merit and societal contributions.


Intellectual Merit The PINC project developed a unique curriculum that integrates biology and computer science. This interdisciplinary approach enabled students from life sciences to acquire computational skills essential for modern scientific research. The curriculum, refined over multiple iterations, now includes:




PINC Minor: A 15-unit interdisciplinary program designed for life science students.




Data Science and Machine Learning Certificate: A 12-unit program targeting students interested in biotechnology applications.




Professional Certificate for Genentech Employees: A 15-unit asynchronous program co-developed with Genentech, tailored for working professionals.




These programs collectively enhanced computational literacy among students and working professionals. The project also created state-of-the-art teaching materials, such as hands-on projects and lecture videos, to ensure effective learning.

Increasing Diversity in STEM: The project focused on supporting students from underrepresented backgrounds. Student Success Stories: Several PINC alumni have achieved significant milestones:




Internships at leading companies such as Genentech and GitHub.

Industry Collaboration: Collaboration with Genentech led to the creation of scholarships, professional development workshops, and mock interview sessions. Over 67 students benefited from Gen-PINC scholarships, which provided financial support and reduced barriers to participation.




Mentorship and Community Building: The program emphasized near-peer mentorship to foster a sense of community. Expansion to Other Programs: Inspired by the success of PINC, additional grants were secured to expand peer mentoring and redesign introductory CS courses across San Francisco State University (SFSU) and other CSU campuses. These initiatives aim to improve retention and engagement among historically marginalized students in computing.




Key Outcomes




Curriculum Development: Successful institutionalization of the PINC minor and certificate programs.




Student Achievements: Significant placements in internships, jobs, and graduate schools.




Professional Development: Enhanced industry readiness through seminars and mock interviews.




Dissemination: Presentations at conferences and publications in peer-reviewed journals.




Conclusion The PINC project has had a profound impact on students, faculty, and industry partners by fostering inclusivity in computer science education. Through innovative curriculum design, robust community building, and strategic industry collaboration, the project has set a benchmark for interdisciplinary education and broadened participation in STEM fields. As the program continues to evolve, its legacy will inspire further initiatives aimed at creating equitable learning environments in computing.


For more information, please visit https://pinc.sfsu.edu.
